news.title: President leaves for Tanzania
news.content:
Fungi Kwaramba, News Editor

President Mnangagwa has departed for Tanzania to participate in an extraordinary summit involving regional leaders from SADC (Southern African Development Community) and the East Africa Community (EAC).

The summits primary focus is to address the escalating security crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

As the SADC Chairperson, President Mnangagwa has underscored Africas commitment to silencing the guns in DRC.

His departure was marked by a send-off at Robert Mugabe International Airport, attended by Vice President Constantino Chiwenga, various Cabinet ministers, and service chiefs.

He was also accompanied by Defence Minister Oppah Muchinguri Kashiri.

This summit reflects a collaborative effort by African nations to tackle regional security challenges.

news.title: President leaves for joint SADC – EAC Summit on DRC
news.content:
Following the SADC Summit that was held last week in Harare, President Mnangagwa is today expected to leave for Tanzania, where he will join other Heads of State and Government for a crucial summit that is expected to end the conflict in the Eastern parts of DRC.

The mineral-rich Eastern DRC has been dogged by conflict for more than 30 years, with fighters from the M23 rebel group recently capturing almost all of Goma  a major city of more than a million people in the east of DR Congo.

The fighting has caused mass casualties and the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people in DRC.

For this reason, regional leaders from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the East African Community (EAC) will hold a historic joint Extraordinary Summit of the Heads of State and Government in Tanzania tomorrow to deal with the security situation in DRC.

Our Political Editor, Fungi Kwaramba, will give live updates of the event over the next two days. Stay informed on this important issue.

news.title: Lift African Woman Up Foundation empowers women and girls in conflict  management
news.content:
Leonard Ncube ,[emailprotected]

The newly formed Lift African Woman Up Foundation will this Saturday hold a special session for the first time in Victoria Falls to empower women and girls in conflict management and building confidence.

Founded by Mrs Lwazi Mbowa, the founder of Miss Big Matofotofo, the foundation seeks to address challenges faced by women as a result of often-overlooked struggles such as relationships, depression, anxiety, domestic violence, and infidelity.

The foundation was launched in Bulawayo and is now expanding to Victoria Falls, with three speakers: Ms Mejury Maphosa, Mr Ezra Tshisa Sibanda, and Ms Gertrude Ndlovu, while Mrs Mbowa will be the host. The venue will be Irock Lodge.

The focus will be on family feuds, conflict management, victim support, managing infidelity, instilling confidence in vulnerable women and girls, and teaching survival skills.

The theme for the programme is: Lift her up and set her on.

Mrs Mbowa said she founded the organisation after attending a workshop where she realised that women were facing numerous challenges, with many lacking the knowledge of how to address them.

The Saturday event is targeting women, while men can attend to listen, as the focus is on starting by building up women in the home before extending to men.

Mrs Mbowa said women should be empowered to handle domestic violence, particularly infidelity by men, and not simply opt out, as most of them end up becoming girlfriends to married men and go through similar traumatising experiences.

The focus is to uplift every woman because they take responsibility for things that happen in their families. When children get into drugs, this affects women, and sometimes some children are affected by domestic violence at home, which in turn impacts their mothers.

Some children are abused by elderly men who give them money and even infect them with diseases, leaving them as victims, and this affects their mothers. Some men even have girlfriends, and this causes depression in their spouses, who carry the burden. So, we have a speaker who will unpack why men have girlfriends and how women can relate to cheating men other than fighting or giving them love potions, said Mrs Mbowa.

She said another speaker will address how women can rise up, be smart, and take pride in themselves without confronting the so-called girlfriend.

The speaker will focus on how women whose husbands are cheating can become independent, find something to do, and stay busy. We want women to know how they can conduct themselves before their husbands, family, children, society, and the girlfriend herself. We will also focus on how depression affects life, and obviously, people will have an opportunity to interact and ask questions, she said.

We want to uplift women and the girl child so they dont leave their marriages but seek to be educated, employed, and have a strategy to deal with a cheating man because fighting only leads to trouble with the law, and leaving a marriage may see one ending up becoming a girlfriend to another married man.

Mrs Mbowa urged women not to live in pretence but to face challenges head-on with respect, peace, and humility.

She said she and others are also advocating for leniency on behalf of women who get arrested for domestic violence caused by cheating men.

news.title: Fatal launched to empower communities with first aid skills through theatre
news.content:
Mthabisi Tshuma,[emailprotected]

A new and exciting edutainment initiative, First Aid Theatre Action Live (Fatal), has been launched as an innovative community empowerment project that merges theatre arts with first aid training to boost community knowledge and preparedness for emergencies.

With the belief that every individual has the potential to save lives, the initiative explores the intersection of creative expression and practical skill-building.

Kukhanyakwenkosi Ganja Mnkandla

Fatal project manager, Kukhanyakwenkosi Ganja Mnkandla, explained that the project aims to address the critical gap in basic first aid knowledge, particularly in rural and semi-urban areas where access to emergency medical services is limited.

This concept was born after we attended a Red Cross first aid training course. As theatre practitioners, we discussed how important basic first aid training is for communities in line with lifes emergencies. We realised that we could use the power of theatre to engage and empower communities while teaching first aid, said Mnkandla.

The project will share the importance of immediate, informed action during accidents or health crises. Through interactive theatre performances, Fatal will depict real-life scenarios requiring urgent medical intervention and teach audiences how to administer first aid effectively while waiting for professional help.

These performances, developed and enacted by trained community youth, will cover common emergencies like road accidents, snake bites, choking, burns, and fainting, Mnkandla explained.

The aim is to ensure people know how to act in an emergency situation.

In addition to teaching first aid, Fatal seeks to challenge misconceptions about first aid and integrate culturally relevant narratives to resonate with local communities.

The use of theatre as an edutainment tool makes the message not only informative but memorable, using storytelling to create a lasting impact, he added.

Ganja Mnkandla, a creative entrepreneur with a disability, brings a wealth of experience to the project. His journey in the arts began in school drama and later evolved into community theatre, where he became the founding director of the nationally acclaimed Zalabantu Theatre Arts. He also played a key role in the production of 1983-The Dark Years, which was nominated for Outstanding Theatre Production at the 2019 National Arts Merit Awards (Nama). Mnkandla is also a professional filmmaker trained at the Zimbabwe Film and Television School of Southern Africa. His notable work includes the short film Nompilo and the 13-episode documentary series Ezenkosi, funded by the Broadcasting Authority of Zimbabwe.

Additionally, Mnkandla holds a certificate in basic industrial first aid training from the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society. His versatility as an artist, both behind and in front of the camera, enriches the Fatal project with his passion for storytelling and dedication to community empowerment.

news.title: Asante Mo Drops second single ‘Wangala’
news.content:
Mthabisi Tshuma,[emailprotected]

Talented creative group Asante Mo has released their second single, titled Wangala, featuring Tizzie and produced at Tizzie Studios.

Following their debut track Going Away, Wangala comes with visuals that feature Zimkids Orphan Trust and are directed by Praise Nkala, under Zizo Motion Pictures Production.

One of the groups founders, Newman Trinidad, shared that Wangala is part of a series of works the group is set to release in 2025, marking the growth of their brand as they aim to make an international impact.This song celebrates unity, as it talks about people coming together from different tribes to celebrate their diverse cultures. When one of our cast members dreamt of a place called Wangala, where people from different tribes gathered in peace, love, and unity, we created this beautiful piece, said Trinidad.

Were also working on our new production Indandanda #PowerOfPercussion, which will be launched in Harare this April. This show speaks the language of Southern Africa and is a powerful production, with many local artistes believing in the power of percussion, he added.Additionally, the group is collaborating with Iyasa on their third track, which is shaping up well, with Trinidad promising fans more Afro-tech this year.

news.title: Bulawayo stakeholders discuss proposed standalone water utility
news.content:
Online Reporter

STAKEHOLDERS in Bulawayo have gathered at the Council Chambers today to discuss the local authoritys proposed decision to establish a standalone water utility company.The council has begun by explaining what is involved in setting up a private water utility company for the local authority.Council officials have stated that by ring-fencing its water budgets, it stands to improve services.The proposed Water and Sanitation Public Utility will be wholly owned by the council.Deliberations will also address the ownership of assets for the new utility.The council will remain the asset owner, while the proposed utility will manage the assets.The proposed utility aligns with government plans for the privatisation of water resources in local authorities.The proposed utility will be run by a seven-member board, which will report to the council.

news.title: Paddonhurst woman steals from brother; breaks into safe
news.content: Trish Mukwazo,[emailprotected]A 31-year-old woman from Paddonhurst suburb in Bulawayo has been sentenced to nine months in prison for stealing R4,000 from her brother.Nothabo Ndlovu who stayed with his brother took advantage of his absence and hired a locksmith to break open the safe before stealing the money and some crucial documents.Ndlovu, who had been in custody, heaved a sigh of relief after Bulawayo magistrate Mr Abednico Ndebele suspended four months on condition that she restitutes the money stolen from her brother, Mr Sifanele Dlamini by the end of March.Mr Ndebele further suspended another five months for three years on condition that she does not commit a crime of a similar nature within that period.In passing the sentence Mr Ndebele took into consideration that Ndlovu is a first-time offender who pleaded guilty and did not waste the courts time.He however noted that the victim lost a lot of money.First-time offenders are rewarded by leniency, he said.In mitigation, Ndlovu submitted that she is a single mother of one who stole the money out of desperation to cater for her sons financial needs.Prosecutor, Ms Nkanyezi Xaba, said on 28 January this year, Mr Dlamini left for Harare where he works.When he came back he discovered the theft and reported the case to the police leading to the accuseds arrest, said Ms Xaba.Dlamini just recovered the documents and as such was prejudiced of 4 000 rand.

news.title: Rainfall to begin tomorrow, intensifying next week
news.content:
Online Reporter

The Meteorological Services Department (MSD) has announced that most parts of the country will begin receiving rainfall from tomorrow, with the wet spell expected to intensify into the coming week.

This follows a dry spell that has persisted for nearly two to three weeks in some regions of the country.

According to the MSDs daily weather report, areas such as Gwanda, Matopos, Binga, Harare, Kwekwe, Marondera, Mutare, and Masvingo will experience rains tomorrow, while the rest of the country will start receiving downpours on Sunday.

The rainfall recorded so far has sparked optimism for a good harvest in most communities, and the livestock situation has also improved significantly.

news.title: Overtaking attempt ends in disaster
news.content:
Sinokubonga Nkala,[emailprotected]

A 62-year-old Tongaat Hulett employee has been sentenced to two years in prison after his overtaking attempt on the Ngundu-Tanganda road resulted in a fatal crash, killing one passenger and injuring the driver and others.

The Zimbabwe Road Traffic Act obligates drivers to drive at a safe speed, obey traffic signs, maintain proper control of the vehicle, and exercise caution when overtaking.

On 4 August 2024, John Manyere was behind the wheel of a white Toyota Land Cruiser, heading east on the Ngundu-Tanganda road with five passengers.

As he approached the 84km marker, Manyere attempted to overtake a large haulage truck but lost control of the vehicle, veering sharply into the right lane.

In a statement on X, the National Prosecuting Authority of Zimbabwe (NPAZ) said: The vehicle veered off the road and plunged into a water canal.

A passenger was tragically washed away in the crash, and her body was later recovered at Siphon 14, near Buffalo Range.

The driver and the rest of the passengers sustained injuries, said the NPAZ.

The driver was found to be negligent in several key areas, including excessive speeding, failing to take evasive action when the accident became imminent, ignoring a warning traffic sign, losing control of the vehicle, and failing to exercise caution while overtakingall of which contributed to the tragic crash.

Manyeres driving privileges were revoked for two years.

news.title: Kwekwe Duo Slapped with 25-Year Jail Term for Murder
news.content: Ronald Mpofu, Online ReporterThe Midlands Special High Court Circuit has sentenced two men from Kwekwe to 25 years in prison for murder.Obey Mtombeni (29) and Prosper Hone (24) were convicted for assaulting and stabbing Blessing Muza, who succumbed to the injuries and died upon arrival at the hospital.According to a statement by the National Prosecuting Authority of Zimbabwe (NPAZ) on December 3, 2022, the now-deceased Muza and his brothers were at the Mbizo Inn club.He (Muza) went outside to relieve himself and saw the accused persons assaulting Tinotenda Nyama. He tried to intervene, and the accused persons assaulted him with clenched fists all over his body before stabbing him on the left side of the chest. He managed to escape and ran back to his brothers, who rushed him to hospital, where he was pronounced dead upon arrival, read the statement.The duo (Mthombeni and Hone) was convicted and sentenced by the High Court sitting in Gweru.This sentencing is part of the courts efforts to clear its backlog of cases, having recently completed 60 cases by the end of last month. The Midlands High Court Circuit has been handling various cases, including murder trials, with significant progress reported in Gweru and Gokwe. This special circuit court was established to address a backlog of over 500 cases dating back to 2019.
